FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_prev_prog_3.Description: Bromine processes are all related in basic chemical technology. All prevention measures stated here would apply to all processes using bromine. Compliance with the requirements of 40 CFR68.65 (a) was achieved as follows:BROMODIPA 3/16/12. PHAs are performed using the Hazop technique.

Chlorine processes are all related in basic chemical technology. All prevention measures stated here would apply to all processes using bromine. Compliance with the requirements of 40 CFR68.65 (a) was achieved as follows: TRIONE STEP 4 8/23/07. PHAs are performed using the Hazop technique.

Ethyl Chloride processes are all related n basic chemical technology. All prevention measures stated here would apply to all processes using ethyl chloride. Compliance with the requirements of 40 CFR68.65 (a) was achieved as follows:TES 5/21/09. PHAs are performed using the Hazop technique.

Trichlorosilane processes are related in basic chemical technology. All prevention measures stated here should apply to all processes using trichlorosilane 5/21/09. Compliance with the requirements of 40 CFR68.65(a) was acheived as follows:TES 5/21/09. PHAs are performed using the Hazop technique.

Vinyl Chloride processes are all related in basic chemical technology. All prevention measures stated here would apply to all processes using vinyl chloride. Compliance with the requirements of 40 CFR68.65 (a) was achieved as follows:VINYL MAGNESIUM CHLORIDE 6/25/08. PHAs are performed using the Hazop technique.

PropylChloroformate processes are all related in bassic chemical technology. all prevention measures stated here would apply to all pocesses using propylchloroformate. Complieance with the requirements of 40 CFR 68.65(a) was achieved as follows: PMT 5/18/2013.

Hydrazine (100%) processes are all related in basic chemical technology. All prevention measures stated here would apply to all processes using hydrazine. Compliance with the requirements of 40 CFR 68.65(a) was achieved as follows: PMT 5/18/2013, Amdro 1/18/2013. PHAs are performed using the Hazop technique.

Monoethylamine processes are all related in basic chemical technology. All prevention measures stated heere would apply to all processes using monoethylamine. Compliance with the requirements of 40 CFR 68.65(a) was acheived as follows: Flumetralin 10/4/2010. PHA's are performed using the Hazop technique.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Weylchem US Inc. is a multi-purpose batch chemical manufacturing facility located in Elgin, South Carolina. The facility is situated in the southern sector of approximately 200 acres of contiguous land. Surrounding property is rural/residential/farmland.  Weylchem has a mature process safety management program in place, designed to minimize and control the potential risks presented by the processes at this site.  Management at the site are committed to ensuring that the facility is operated in a safe manner, protecting the employees, environment and surrounding community.



Reduction in inventory and substitution of RMP chemicals is considered when and where feasible. To this end, bromine inventory is substantially reduced at this time. In addition, three RMP chemicals have been added and two RMP chemical have been eliminated.



Weylchem utilizes 8 RMP regulated chemicals in quantities above the threshold; bromine, chlorine, ethyl chloride, trichlorosilane, vinyl chloride, propylchloroformate, hydrazine,and monoethylamine. For each of these chemicals measures have been taken to prevent and/or mitigate potential for accidental releases. Efforts for each chemical are detailed below.



Bromine is also used in several processes at Weylchem. All bromine storage tanks, receivers, and pumps are housed in two containment buildings. These vessels are also diked inside the containment buildings, and are equipped with deluge systems for the dikes in the event of a release. Both bromine buildings are vented to emergency scrubbers. In the event of a storage vessel failure and containment of the bromine in a dike, the bromine sensors will immediately activate the emergency scrubbers and safely evacuate the vapor space of the building. The scrubbers can be activated manually or automatically by bromine/chlorine located inside the containment buildings.



Bromine off-gasses from manufacturing processes are vented through acid absorbers and caustic scrubbers. Bromine is stored i

n lead lined storage tanks designed with a pressure rating of 50 psig. Bromine is weighed on a batch basis for individual processes into glass lined receivers. All bromine tanks and receivers are diked and housed in containment buildings.



Measures are in place to prevent accidental releases from the bromine tanks and receivers. All storage tanks and receivers are equipped with rupture discs and relief valves. A corrosion resistant rupture disc is installed just above the vessel shell. Above the rupture disc is a pressure relief valve. In the event that over-pressurization bursts the rupture disc, the relief valve would control the release by allowing the overpressure to relieve to the point of the relief valve only. This would minimize the amount of bromine released to the building. The rupture disc protects the relief valve from corrosion. A pressure indicator is installed between the rupture disc and relief valve for protection of rupture disc failure.



Bromine is received on site in tank trailers and off loaded into one of three storage tanks via pressure. The tank truck is parked inside the containment building while unloading. All connections are bolted flanges, and all transfer lines are teflon-lined steel construction. Material handler personnel are present during the entire unloading operation.



Chlorine is currently used in several processes at Weylchem. It is received and used in 1 ton cylinders only. Cylinders are stored inside specially constructed containment buildings equipped with sensors for leak detection. Each chlorine building is equipped with an emergency scrubber capable of safely evacuating the contents of a one a ton cylinder within 45 minutes. Chlorine is vaporized in a unit contained in the buildings and transferred to production equipment as a vapor, which minimizes the quantity of chlorine in the piping. Piping outside the containment building is enclosed in corrosion resistant piping ductwork. The ductwork directs any piping leakag

e back to the containment building where sensors will detect the leak and activate the emergency scrubber(s). The ductwork is easily opened for inspection and repair.



As an administrative control, no more than one chlorine cylinder is open to the plant manifold at any one time. Chlorine addition is typically interlocked to batch reactor agitation and temperature alarms to prevent transfer when these parameters are out of spec.



Ethyl Chloride is currently used in only one process at this facility. The ethyl chloride is stored in a pressurized storage tank with a nitrogen blanket on the tank. The storage area for ethyl chloride is equipped with a remote activation fixed foam system for fire suppression.



Trichlorosilane is used in 1 process at the site. It is stored in DOT specification cylinders. 



Vinyl chloride is used in 1 process at the Weylchem facility and is stored in 120 gallon cylinders. These cylinders drums inside of a containment building that is vented to a caustic scrubber in the event any material should be spilled. When vinyl chloride is charge to the process ventilation is provided both at the cylinder connection and in the process vessel. During the charging process area monitoring is performed for any leaks of vinyl chloride.



Propylchloroformate is used in 1 process at the Weylchem facility and is stored in 55 gallon drums. These drums are stored inside a flammable materials warehouse. The propylchloroformate is charged to the process thru a reactor/receiver system vented thru a caustic scrubber to the thermal oxidizer.



Hydrazine is used in 2 processes (one as 64% material and one as 85%) at the Weylchem facility and is stored in 55 gallon drums. These drums are stored inside a main materials warehouse. The hydrazine is charged to the process thru a reactor/receiver system vented thru a caustic scrubber to the thermal oxidizer.



Monoethylamine is used in 1 process (as a 70% solution) at the Weylchem facility and is stored in 55 ga

llon drums. These drums are stored inside a flammable materials warehouse. The monoethylamine is charged to the process thru a reactor/receiver system vented thru a caustic scrubber to the thermal oxidizer.



Weylchem has a well organized, highly trained emergency response group (fire brigade) which is the first line of defense in response to any release. Trained firefighters, hazmat responders and first responders are all a part of this group. Weylchem also has coordinated agreements with the local LEPC, which consists of local and county fire departments, nearby industry response personnel, hospitals, law enforcement, and government personnel. The site is well prepared for response to any potential releases of materials detailed in this plan, and others.



In summary, 4 (four) specially designed containment buildings have been constructed to reduce the likelihood and the severity of potential releases. Each building is equipped with a deluge system and an emergency scrubber to evacuate and treat the vapor space of these buildings in the event of a release. Chlorine and bromine sensors have been installed in the bromine and chlorine buildings and in the appropriate plant areas for leak detection. All bromine and chlorine piping is enclosed in corrosion resistant piping ductwork. The site has a mechanical integrity program for inspection and maintenance of piping, tanks, reactors, and equipment. This program is a valuable tool for prevention and minimization of releases.   



In the five years prior to 5/20/2013 the site did not have any RMP incidents that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.
